newsitem.title: USA: U.S. air ticket tax bill proposed Senate.
newsitem.headline: U.S. air ticket tax bill proposed Senate.

text.p: A bipartisan measure to reinstate the U.S. aviation excise tax was introduced in the Senate on Thursday to help finance the Federal Aviation Administration's safety and security program.

Senator John McCain, chairman of the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, said the bill would revive the 10 percent ticket tax only until next September, by which time a long-range FAA funding plan could be enacted.

The extension includes a 10-percent passenger ticket tax, a 6.25-percent cargo waybill tax, a $6-per-person international departure tax and general aviation fuel taxes, all of which expired on December 31.
McCain, an Arizona Republican, said the FAA fund contains only enough money to finance safety and security operations until early March.
He called for quick action on the bill, which was co-sponsored by Senators Fritz Hollings of South Carolina and Wendell Ford of Kentucky, both Democrats.
McCain said the tax should not be extended for more than a few months until the new funding measures are passed.
"We have a process in place to explore alternative long-term funding mechanisms to ensure the fiscal viability of the FAA and its important safety and security missions," he said.
